its difficult to merge life in its purest form with science, even though science's purpose is to study life.

 
 That's not true -- actually, it doesn't make sense. Science is just a bunch of rules (by definition). "Biology uses science to study life" is true. "Physics uses science to study the physical world" is true, but "science's purpose is to study life" is not true.

Life as energy is clearly wrong, a corpse still has masses of energy in it- they don't suddenly drop to absolute zero.
 
 'Life' is information if anything, the reading from ECGs etc are not reading the energy, but the activity of cells in a system- the transfer of information. 'Life' is really nothing like what you are defining it, it isn't a magic substance that resides in things we think of as alive- it is merely a label we apply to things that show a tendancy to do things we associate with living. What factors these are is still up for debate though, but the fact that there is discussion at the boundaries shows how vague a term it really is.
jim's trucking

No.
 
 According to scientists, the conservation of energy means that it never ceases to exist. It may change form, from potential energy, kinetic energy, chemical energy, heat, light, etc., but it cannot be increased or decreased in regard to its total quantity.
 
 When an object cools, it is merely losing its heat energy to other objects nearby.
 
 When a chemical process "gives off heat", it is merely changing some of the reactant's chemical energy to heat energy.
 
 When light energy is absorbed by an object, it is merely changed to heat energy.
 
 The total amount of energy contained within the universe is fixed...forever!
